The Right to be Forgotten in Federated Learning: An Efficient Realization with Rapid Retraining

Yi Liu1, Lei Xu2, Xingliang Yuan3, Cong Wang1, and Bo Li4 The authors have provided public access to their code and data at github.com/yiliucs/federated-unlearning. 1City University of Hong Kong; 2Nanjing University of Science and Technology;
3Monash University; 4The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology.
{yiliu247, congwang}@cityu.edu.hk, xuleicrypto@gmail.com, xingling.yuan@monash.edu, bli@cse.ust.hk
Abstract

In Machine Learning, the emergence of the right to be forgotten gave birth to a paradigm named machine unlearning, which enables data holders to proactively erase their data from a trained model. Existing machine unlearning techniques focus on centralized training, where access to all holders’ training data is a must for the server to conduct the unlearning process. It remains largely underexplored about how to achieve unlearning when full access to all training data becomes unavailable. One noteworthy example is Federated Learning (FL), where each participating data holder trains locally, without sharing their training data to the central server. In this paper, we investigate the problem of machine unlearning in FL systems. We start with a formal definition of the unlearning problem in FL and propose a rapid retraining approach to fully erase data samples from a trained FL model. The resulting design allows data holders to jointly conduct the unlearning process efficiently while keeping their training data locally. Our formal convergence and complexity analysis demonstrate that our design can preserve model utility with high efficiency. Extensive evaluations on four real-world datasets illustrate the effectiveness and performance of our proposed realization.

I Introduction

The paradigm of “Machine Unlearning” [1] has attracted much attention recently. It has emerged from “the right to be forgotten” [2], where individuals should be entitled to the right to have their private data removed from public directories. This regulated requirement has also set off a privacy-aware technology reform in the context of Machine Learning. From a high-level point of view, the techniques of machine unlearning enable data holders to proactively erase their data from a trained model that memorizes the data. Most of the existing machine unlearning techniques focus on the centralized setting [3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10], where all the training data samples are collected to a server, and later specific samples are requested to be erased via unlearning. However, this setting can be somewhat limited in practice because not all data holders are willing to share data for training due to increasing privacy concerns.

In this paper, we investigate the problem of machine unlearning in a more practical scenario, where data holders are collaboratively performing training and unlearning without sharing raw data. In particular, we target Federated Learning (FL) [11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17], a widely adopted privacy-aware collaborative learning framework. In FL, data holders train a model from their local data samples, and the server only aggregates data holders’ local model updates for data privacy considerations [18]. Despite the above benefit, not allowing the sharing of raw data also poses unique challenges for unlearning in FL.

To erase data samples from a trained FL model, a straightforward approach is to simply train a new model from scratch on the remaining dataset (i.e., excluding the samples that need to be erased) following the original training procedure of FL. However, this approach would be neither practical nor economical for real-world models that are usually trained for weeks from massive training samples. Existing studies on centralized machine unlearning  [8, 5, 6, 7] are not directly applicable because they have to access the raw data during unlearning, which is prohibitive in FL in the first place. Very recently, Liu et al. [19] proposed an approach called FedEraser that aims to address this problem in FL. Unfortunately, this approach has two drawbacks. First, FedEraser only initiates the unlearning algorithm among the clients that request data removal. Namely, other clients’ models still hold the contributions of the data to be removed, which will later be aggregated in a global model. Second, their proposed algorithm utilizes the latest rounds of local model updates to approximate the current unlearned model update. However, the data samples to be removed can be used for training from the very beginning, and the utilized model updates may still consist of the trace of those samples.

Erasing data samples from a trained FL model is non-trivial. To better understand the problem, we first identify two unique challenges in the context of FL as follows.

(C1.) Training is interactive. In FL, the client holds data locally and iteratively exchanges model updates with the server to learn a shared global model. In this context, it is challenging for the central server to erase the contribution of the client data to the model. The key reason is that the client continuously shares the knowledge learned from the local dataset with other clients via model aggregation.

(C2.) Training is incremental. Training in FL is also an incremental procedure in which any given local update reflects all previous updates that occurred on the client. Suppose the global model is updated based on the local model updates that specific clients generate at a particular training round. In that case, all subsequent model updates will implicitly relate to the model updates of these clients.

Our Contributions. To address the above challenges, we deem that the best mechanism so far for data erasure in FL is to perform retraining among all the data holders, so as to completely eliminate the contributions of data samples to be removed. Then the key problem is how to design a rapid retraining approach in FL while preserving model utility. Specifically, we propose a distributed Newton-type model update algorithm, which follows the Quasi-Newton method [20] and utilizes the first-order Taylor expansion to approximate the loss function trained by the local optimizer on the remaining dataset, i.e., the one excludes the removed data samples. To further reduce the cost of retraining, we employ diagonal empirical Fisher Information Matrix (FIM) [21] to efficiently and accurately approximate the inverse Hessian vector to avoid the expensive cost of directly calculating it. To preserve model utility, we apply the momentum technique to the diagonal empirical FIM to alleviate the error caused by the approximation techniques and make the model convergence faster and more stable. The contributions of this paper are listed as follow:

  • •

    We formally define the data erasure problem in federated learning and propose an efficient and effective retraining algorithm. Our proposed algorithm is model agnostic and can naturally be integrated to the framework of FL.

  • •

    We customize a retraining algorithm based on the diagonal empirical FIM for FL, by observing the first-order Taylor expansion of the loss function during the unlearning process. We introduce an adaptive momentum technique to reduce approximation errors in retraining.

  • •

    We conduct a formal convergence analysis over our proposed algorithm and analyze the time and space complexity. Theoretical analysis results show that our algorithm converges to the true optimization path of the strongly convex objectives.

  • •

    We implement our design and conduct extensive experiments over four datasets in terms of the ability to achieve unlearning, efficiency, model performance, and parameter sensitivity. Compared to the baseline retraining, our approach can achieve a speedup of 9.1×9.1\times with an accuracy loss of 2.235 ×10−3absentsuperscript103\times 10^{-3} on the large dataset CelebA.

II Related Work

Our work is related to a line of studies on machine unlearning. Based on the methodology and target problems, they can be classified into two categories, exact unlearning methods and approximate unlearning methods.

Exact Unlearning Methods. These methods are designed to achieve machine unlearning in such a way that the produced models are effectively the same as the ones obtained with retraining. To be specific, they introduce a notion called certified data erasure, which is a theoretical guarantee that a model from which data is removed cannot be distinguished from a model that never observed the data to begin with. Following this objective, some existing work [22, 23, 6, 24, 5] proposes unlearning methods for simple machine models, such as linear regression models, Random Forests models, and k𝑘k-nearest neighbors models. However, these unlearning methods are not suitable for complex nonlinear models (e.g., deep learning models) [8]. On the other hand, these designs cannot directly be applied in FL, because they cannot erase the unlearned data samples’ contributions (i.e., learned knowledge) shared by the clients in FL.

Approximate Unlearning Methods. Intuitively, these methods aim to achieve higher efficiency of machine unlearning through the relaxation of the effectiveness and certifiability requirements [5, 25]. Most of them [10, 3, 8] ask the server to utilize historical gradients and model weights to efficiently approximate the gradients in the unlearning process. However, recent work [26, 27] demonstrated that an attacker (e.g., a malicious central server) can exploit the client’s local gradients to implement an attack to reconstruct the private training samples of the client. Therefore, the above methods may expose the client’s private data to the server and are not desired for FL. A recent design [19] is closely related to our work, which aims to design an efficient retraining algorithm called FedEraser to achieve unlearning in FL. As mentioned before, this work cannot fully erase the contributions of data samples to be removed from the trained model. Besides, it follows the above approximate methods, where the server utilizes cached historical gradients from clients to approximate the current unlearned gradient, which may lead to serious privacy leakage on data holders’ data samples, e.g., gradient leakage attacks [26, 15].

III-B Machine Unlearning Pipeline

In the context of ML, the emergence of the right to be forgotten gave birth to a paradigm called machine unlearning, which enriches the life cycle of traditional ML pipelines by offering data deletion functions. To be specific, machine unlearning pipelines include how the model is trained, employed for inference, incremental update, and conducted a series of data deletions, while retraining from scratch [28].

Training Stage: In the machine unlearning setting, we consider a service provider 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and K𝐾K data owners, where K𝐾K data owners share the data with the service provider to form a initial training dataset 𝒟=𝒟i​n​i​t𝒟subscript𝒟𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}=\mathcal{D}_{init}. Notably, the data owner can initiate a data deletion request to the service provider at any time during the life cycle of the pipeline to perform data deletion. Therefore, the initial training dataset 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} is not always constant, which is a subset of the initial training dataset, i.e., 𝒟⊆𝒟i​n​i​t𝒟subscript𝒟𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡{\mathcal{D}}\subseteq\mathcal{D}_{init}. Specifically, if service provider deletes some data samples from 𝒟i​n​i​tsubscript𝒟𝑖𝑛𝑖𝑡\mathcal{D}_{init}, thus, we have: 𝒟←𝒟\𝒟m←𝒟\𝒟subscript𝒟𝑚{\mathcal{D}}\leftarrow\mathcal{D}\backslash{\mathcal{D}_{m}}, where 𝒟msubscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m} is the deleted data subset. So we use 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D} represents the currently available training dataset. The loss or objective function for a general machine learning model is defined as:

minω∈ℝdℒ​(ω),where ​ℒ​(ω)=1n​∑i=1nℓi​(ω)+λ2​‖ω‖2,subscript𝜔superscriptℝ𝑑ℒ𝜔where ℒ𝜔1𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscriptℓ𝑖𝜔𝜆2subscriptnorm𝜔2\mathop{\min}\limits_{\omega\in{\mathbb{R}^{d}}}\mathcal{L}(\omega),\text{where\quad}\mathcal{L}(\omega)=\frac{1}{n}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{{\ell_{i}}(\omega)}+\frac{\lambda}{2}||\omega|{|_{2}}, (2)

where the above equation captures the average loss of the model, ω𝜔\omega represents the model parameter, ℓi​(ω)subscriptℓ𝑖𝜔\ell_{i}(\omega) represents the loss of the i𝑖i-th data samples (e.g., cross-entropy loss), and λ𝜆\lambda is the regularization constant parameter to prevent over-fitting. If we use mini-batch stochastic gradient descent (SGD) to update model parameter, then for t=1,…,T𝑡1…𝑇t=1,\ldots,T, we have: ωt+1←ω−ηB​∑i=1n∇ℓi​(ωt),←subscript𝜔𝑡1𝜔𝜂𝐵superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛∇subscriptℓ𝑖subscript𝜔𝑡{\omega_{t+1}}\leftarrow\omega-\frac{\eta}{B}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}\nabla{\ell_{i}}({\omega_{t}}), where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate and B𝐵B is the mini-batch size, and model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} can be obtained by incremental update using the above equations. Service providers can deploy this model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} to provide inference services.

Inference Stage: At this stage, the data holder can submit a service request to the service provider at any time, that is, upload the data sample xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} to the server and expect to obtain the corresponding prediction result yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}. The service provider utilizes the currently available model ω𝜔\omega to output the inference results to the data holders through the pipeline API. Furthermore, the data holder can also initiate data deletion requests to the service provider at any time, which will prompt the pipeline to proceed to the unlearning stage.

Unlearning Stage: When the data holders finish requesting data deletion, the server performs the data deletion operation to obtain the remaining training dataset 𝒟u←𝒟\𝒟m←subscript𝒟𝑢\𝒟subscript𝒟𝑚{\mathcal{D}_{u}}\leftarrow\mathcal{D}\backslash{\mathcal{D}_{m}}. The goal is to erase the contribution of the deleted data samples 𝒟msubscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m} from the current model ω𝜔\omega, that is, execute the unlearning algorithm to “unlearn” the deleted dataset 𝒟msubscript𝒟𝑚\mathcal{D}_{m}. For the unlearning algorithm, a naive method is retraining from scratch, i.e., applying mini-batch SGD directly over the dataset 𝒟usubscript𝒟𝑢\mathcal{D}_{u} (we use ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} to denote the corresponding model parameter). Then, run: ωt+1u←ωtu−ηB−Δ​Bt​∑i∈𝒟u∇ℓi​(ωtu),←superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢𝜂𝐵Δsubscript𝐵𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑢∇subscriptℓ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢\omega_{t+1}^{u}\leftarrow\omega_{t}^{u}-\frac{\eta}{{B-\Delta B_{t}}}\sum\limits_{i\in{\mathcal{D}_{u}}}{\nabla{\ell_{i}}(}\omega_{t}^{u}), where Δ​BΔ𝐵\Delta B is the size of the subset removed from the t𝑡t-th mini-batch. In this context, the goal is to minimize the following objective function: ℒu​(ω)=1|𝒟u|​∑i∈𝒟uℓi​(ω).superscriptℒ𝑢𝜔1subscript𝒟𝑢subscript𝑖subscript𝒟𝑢subscriptℓ𝑖𝜔{\mathcal{L}^{u}}(\omega)=\frac{1}{{|{\mathcal{D}_{u}}|}}\sum\nolimits_{i\in{\mathcal{D}_{u}}}{{\ell_{i}}(\omega).}

IV Problem definition

IV-A Formalizing the Problem of Federated Unlearning

We now formalize the data erasure problem in FL. In our setting, the server 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} controls the whole training process by collecting and aggregating model updates uploaded by the clients and these clients 𝒞={C1,C2,…,Ck},k∈{1,…,K}formulae-sequence𝒞subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2…subscript𝐶𝑘𝑘1…𝐾{\mathcal{C}}=\{{C_{1}},{C_{2}},\ldots,{C_{k}}\},k\in\{1,\ldots,K\} hold different local datasets 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathcal{D}_{k}}. In particular, we enable the client to have the control to erase data, i.e., the client can request the server to delete some specific data samples. First, we introduce the concepts of federated data deletion operation. Here, we use the term “learned client” to refer to those clients that have not performed data erasure, and the term “unlearned client” to refer to those clients that perform data erasure. We assume that there are unlearned clients Cku={C1′,C2′,…,Cku′},ku∈{1,…,K}\kcformulae-sequencesubscript𝐶subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝐶1′superscriptsubscript𝐶2′…superscriptsubscript𝐶subscript𝑘𝑢′subscript𝑘𝑢\1…𝐾subscript𝑘𝑐{C_{{k_{u}}}}=\{{C_{1}^{\prime}},{C_{2}^{\prime}},\ldots,{C_{{k_{u}}}^{\prime}}\},{k_{u}}\in\{1,\ldots,K\}\backslash{k_{c}} that initiate deletion requests to the server, where kcsubscript𝑘𝑐k_{c} is the index of learned client set Ckcsubscript𝐶subscript𝑘𝑐C_{k_{c}}. Note that when kc=0subscript𝑘𝑐0k_{c}=0, it is a special case such that all clients initiate deletion requests to the server.

Definition 1.

(Federated Data Deletion Operation). A deletion u𝑢u is a pair (Ω,o)Ω𝑜(\Omega,o) where Ω∈𝒟Ω𝒟\Omega\in\mathcal{D} is a data sample and o𝑜o is a deletion request. A deleted sequence 𝒰𝒰\mathcal{U} is a sequence (u1,u2,…,ui)subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2…subscript𝑢𝑖({u_{1}},{u_{2}},\ldots,u_{i}) where ui∈𝒟×osubscript𝑢𝑖𝒟𝑜{u_{i}}\in\mathcal{D}\times o for all i𝑖i. For the k𝑘k-th client, given a local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} and a deleted sequence 𝒰ksubscript𝒰𝑘\mathcal{U}_{k}, the deletion operation is defined as follows:

𝒟ku=𝒟k∘𝒰k≜𝒟k\{Ω}i=1Rk,superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢subscript𝒟𝑘subscript𝒰𝑘≜\subscript𝒟𝑘superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑖1subscript𝑅𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}={\mathcal{D}_{k}}\circ{\mathcal{U}_{k}}\triangleq{\mathcal{D}_{k}}\backslash\{\Omega\}_{i=1}^{{R_{k}}}, (3)

where Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} is the number of deleted data samples. For example, an unlearned client deletes Rksubscript𝑅𝑘R_{k} (Rk≪nk)much-less-thansubscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝑛𝑘({R_{k}}\ll{n_{k}}) (i.e., 𝒰k={u1,u2,…,uRk}subscript𝒰𝑘subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2…subscript𝑢subscript𝑅𝑘\mathcal{U}_{k}=\{u_{1},u_{2},\ldots,u_{R_{k}}\}) data samples from the local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k} according to the designed data delete operation to obtain the deleted dataset 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}.

By Definition 1, we formalize the problem of federated unlearning as a game between two entities: the service provider 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} and the client set 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. The service provider can be a central aggregator that collects model updates from various clients, where each client Cksubscript𝐶𝑘C_{k} holds different local dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘{\mathcal{D}_{k}}. Service providers use the collected model updates to update and obtain the FL model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*}. Any unlearned client Cku⊆𝒞subscript𝐶subscript𝑘𝑢𝒞C_{k_{u}}\subseteq\mathcal{C} can revoke the contribution of his data 𝒟ku∈{Ω}i=1Rksuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscriptΩ𝑖1subscript𝑅𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}\in\{\Omega\}_{i=1}^{{R_{k}}} to ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} by using the specified unlearning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}.

To this end, the service provider has to erase the client’s data contribution and retrain any trained global models ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} to produce ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u}, that is, the contribution of the data 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u} is not in the ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} model. It is conceivable that the parameters of ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} and ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} are similar (despite stochasticity in learning), and it is desired for their performance (in terms of test accuracy) to be comparable. However, the fact that model ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} was obtained by training on the remaining dataset from scratch provides a certificate to the data owner that their data share was indeed removed. Certified data erasure is defined as a theoretical guarantee that a model from which data is removed cannot be distinguished from a model that never observed the data to begin with. This conveys a very strong notion of privacy. Therefore, our goal is to make service providers revoke the contribution of specified data samples to the global model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} while maintaining this model’s performance. The federated unlearning problem is defined as follows:

Definition 2.

(Federated Unlearning). Let ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} denote the global model produced by the federated learning pipeline, and ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} denote the global model produced by the federated unlearning pipeline. For a given threshold ε⩾0𝜀0\varepsilon\geqslant 0, the federated unlearning problem is defined as: there exists an unlearning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} that makes the following equation hold:

‖T​(ω∗)−T𝒜​(ωu)‖⩽ε,norm𝑇superscript𝜔subscript𝑇𝒜superscript𝜔𝑢𝜀||T({\omega^{*}})-{T_{\mathcal{A}}}({\omega^{u}})||\leqslant\varepsilon, (4)

where T​(⋅)𝑇⋅T(\cdot) denotes the distribution of models learned using unlearning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} and ε𝜀\varepsilon is a small positive number. 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A} achieves unlearning when these two distributions are ε𝜀\varepsilon–identical. In other words, in our work, this evidence (i.e., the output of unlearning algorithm 𝒜𝒜\mathcal{A}) takes the form of a training algorithm, which if implemented correctly, guarantees that the parameter distributions of ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} and ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} are ε𝜀\varepsilon–identical.

IV-B Goals of Federated Unlearning

As discussed in Section III-B, the simple and effective way to achieve federated unlearning is to retrain the global model from scratch on the remaining training dataset. However, such a method is unrealistic for an FL system due to large computing resources and communication overhead. Moreover, to comply with data regulations such as GDPR [2] for continuous data deletion requests, service providers need to retrain the global model frequently. In this paper, we consider this method as a baseline method to compare with our solution. To this end, our proposed solution needs to meet the following goals:

(G1.) Zero Contribution Guarantees: Similar to the baseline, any new unlearning solution should ensure that the erased data has zero contribution to the unlearned model, i.e., the erased data does not influence the model parameters.

(G2.) Privacy Guarantee: Any new unlearning solution should maintain the privacy of the client in the FL settings. Any attacker, including the server, cannot easily utilize gradient information to implement gradient leakage attacks [26].

(G3.) Comparable Accuracy: It is conceivable that there is a trade-off between the performance of the unlearning solution and the accuracy of the model, which indicates that the accuracy of the model would decrease. Even if there is no component of the approach that explicitly promotes high accuracy, any unlearning solution should strive to introduce a small accuracy gap in comparison to the baseline for any number of data samples unlearned.

(G4.) Reduced Retraining Time: Additionally, no matter how many data samples need to be unlearned, any new unlearning solution should be faster than the baseline (or other state-of-the-art unlearning approaches). Namely, any new unlearning solution should not introduce additional computation and communication overhead to the original training procedure, which is already expensive [1].

(G5.) Model Agnostic: The unlearning solution should be general, which means that it can be applied to any model. It should also provide the aforementioned guarantees for the system settings of varying nature and complexity [1, 6].

V Our Design

V-A Federated Unlearning Pipeline

In this section, we present a federated unlearning pipeline, as illustrated in Fig. 1. Specifically, the pipeline includes three stages: training stage, inference stage, and unlearning stage. The training stage and the inference stage is the same as those in FL systems (refer to Section III-A for details). The main difference from FL is that this pipeline adds the two functions, i.e., data deletion and rapid retraining, both of which are included in the unlearning stage. Thus, the details of the unlearning stage are as follows:

Unlearning Stage: (a) Data Deletion: Assuming that the kusubscript𝑘𝑢k_{u}-th unlearned client initiates several data deletion requests 𝒰k={u1,u2,…,uRk}subscript𝒰𝑘subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2…subscript𝑢subscript𝑅𝑘\mathcal{U}_{k}=\{u_{1},u_{2},\ldots,u_{R_{k}}\} to the server before the start of the t𝑡t-th round of training, these clients need to perform data deletion operations, where the remaining local dataset is denoted as 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}. (b) Rapid Retraining: Then all clients execute the proposed unlearning algorithm (see below for more details) on the remaining local dataset 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u} to achieve unlearning. Specifically, to eliminate the influence of unlearned data samples on the FL model, we perform a retrain operation to make the model forget the knowledge represented by these unlearned data samples. In this context, the naive solution (i.e., retraining from scratch) is to apply mini-batch stochastic gradient descent (SGD) directly over the remaining local training dataset 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u} (we use ωtkusuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢\omega_{t}^{k_{u}} to denote the corresponding model parameter), i.e., for k𝑘k-th client, the loss function can be defined as follows:

Fku​(ω)=1B−Δ​Bt​∑(xi,yi)∈𝒟kuℓi​(ω),subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢𝜔1𝐵Δsubscript𝐵𝑡subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢subscriptℓ𝑖𝜔{F_{k_{u}}}(\omega)=\frac{1}{{B-\Delta B_{t}}}\sum\limits_{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}}{{\ell_{i}}(\omega)}, (5)

where B𝐵B is the mini-batch size and Δ​BtΔsubscript𝐵𝑡{\Delta{B_{t}}} is the size of the subset removed from the t𝑡t-th mini-batch. Thus, each client updates its local model by using: ωt+1ku=ωtku−ηB−Δ​Bt​∑(xi,yi)∈𝒟ku∇Fk​(ωtu),superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢𝜂𝐵Δsubscript𝐵𝑡subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}-\frac{\eta}{{B-\Delta{B_{t}}}}\sum\limits_{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}}{\nabla{F_{k}}(\omega_{t}^{u})}, where η𝜂\eta is the learning rate. After executing the local unlearning step, all clients upload model updates to the server so that the server can aggregate these updates to obtain a new unlearned global model. Thus, we have the following execution step. (c) Aggregation: Recall that, to achieve unlearning, all unlearned clients and all learned clients perform local retraining and upload the updates of the unlearned model to the server. Then the server uses the aggregation rules to aggregate the model updates of the unlearned client and other clients. Such an operation can meet the goals G1 and G2. Suppose we use the classic aggregation rule (i.e., FedAvg) to aggregate these updates, the formal definition of this aggregation rule is as follows:

ωt+1u=1Kc​∑pkc​∑kcpkc​ωtkc+1Ku​∑pku​∑kupku​ωtku.superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1𝑢1subscript𝐾𝑐subscript𝑝subscript𝑘𝑐subscriptsubscript𝑘𝑐subscript𝑝subscript𝑘𝑐superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑐1subscript𝐾𝑢subscript𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢subscriptsubscript𝑘𝑢subscript𝑝subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢\omega_{t+1}^{u}=\frac{1}{{{K_{c}}\sum{{p_{{k_{c}}}}}}}\sum\limits_{{k_{c}}}{{p_{{k_{c}}}}\omega_{t}^{{k_{c}}}}+\frac{1}{{{K_{u}}\sum{{p_{{k_{u}}}}}}}\sum\limits_{{k_{u}}}{{p_{{k_{u}}}}\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}}. (6)

Note that user-defined aggregation rules can also be used in our pipeline, which do not affect the operations of it.

V-B Federated Rapid Retraining

Obviously, the baseline is a time-consuming and resource-consuming unlearning solution, which is undesirable for real-world large FL systems. This motivates us to seek a time-saving and energy-efficient rapid retraining solution. To this end, we follow the Quasi-Newton methods [20] and use the first-order Taylor approximation technique to propose an efficient method. Specifically, for the k𝑘k-th client, let ∇Fku​(ω)=0∇subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢𝜔0\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega})=0 around ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*}, we obtain:

∇Fku​(ω∗)+Hku​(ω∗)​(ωu−ω∗)≈0,∇subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢superscript𝜔subscript𝐻subscript𝑘𝑢superscript𝜔superscript𝜔𝑢superscript𝜔0\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}})+{H_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}})({\omega^{u}}-{\omega^{*}})\approx 0, (7)

where ωu=arg⁡min​∇Fku​(ω)superscript𝜔𝑢∇subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢𝜔{\omega^{u}}=\arg\min\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}(\omega) is a unique global minimum (i.e., global optimal unlearned model), Hku​(ω∗)=∇2Fku​(ω∗)subscript𝐻subscript𝑘𝑢superscript𝜔superscript∇2subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢superscript𝜔{H_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}})={\nabla^{2}}{F_{{k_{u}}}}({\omega^{*}}) is the Hessian matrix, and ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} is a minimizer for Fk​(ω)subscript𝐹𝑘𝜔F_{k}(\omega). According to the first-order optimality condition, we have: ωt+1ku=ωtku+1B−Δ​Bt​Hku−1​Δk,superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢1𝐵Δsubscript𝐵𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐻subscript𝑘𝑢1subscriptΔ𝑘\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}+\frac{1}{{B-\Delta{B_{t}}}}H_{{k_{u}}}^{-1}{\Delta_{k}}, where ΔΔ\Delta is the local gradient, i.e., Δku=∇Fk​(ωtku,𝒟ku)subscriptΔsubscript𝑘𝑢∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\Delta_{k_{u}}=\nabla{F_{k}}(\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}), and Hku=∇2Fk​(ωtku,𝒟ku)subscript𝐻subscript𝑘𝑢superscript∇2subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢H_{k_{u}}={\nabla^{2}}{F_{k}}(\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}},\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}). In this way, we can utilize Newton-type update strategy to efficiently achieve unlearning goals. However, the calculation of the inverse Hessian-vector is still computationally expensive. Therefore, we further explore how to efficiently calculate the inverse Hessian matrix Hku−1superscriptsubscript𝐻subscript𝑘𝑢1H_{k_{u}}^{-1}.

To address this problem, recent work [10, 19] uses the limited-memory Broyden Fletcher Goldfarb Shanno (L-BFGS) algorithm [29, 30, 31] by leveraging the historical parameter-gradient pair {(ωtk,∇Fk​(ωtk))}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑘𝑡1𝑇\{(\omega_{t}^{k},\nabla F_{k}(\omega_{t}^{k}))\}_{t=1}^{T} stored in the unlearned client to approximate Hku−1superscriptsubscript𝐻subscript𝑘𝑢1H_{k_{u}}^{-1} for each of T𝑇T iterations. In particular, L-BFGS fits the Hessian matrix through the first m𝑚m historical parameter-gradient pairs without explicitly constructing and storing the approximation of the Hessian matrix or its inverse matrix, and its time and space complexity is 𝒪​(m​n)𝒪𝑚𝑛\mathcal{O}(mn). Nevertheless, L-BFGS algorithms can just efficiently solve the Hessian approximation problem only when the model is small (i.e., generally the model parameter is less than 104superscript10410^{4}, but they cannot be directly applied to the setting of large models (e.g., ResNet [32]). Furthermore, if the server stores historical gradients and parameters, it will incur privacy disclosure risks [26] to the clients.

Motivated by the limitations mentioned above, we aim to answer the following question: how to efficiently approximate the inverse Hessian matrix without utilizing the historical parameter-gradient pair {(ωtk,∇Fk​(ωtk))}t=1Tsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑘∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑘𝑡1𝑇\{(\omega_{t}^{k},\nabla F_{k}(\omega_{t}^{k}))\}_{t=1}^{T} in FL? In this paper, we propose a low-cost Hessian approximation method, i.e., diagonal empirical Fisher Information Matrix (FIM)-based approximation method to efficiently approximate Hessian matrix. So the unlearning update rule can be rewritten as follows:

ωt+1ku=ωtku−1B−Δ​Bt​Γku−1​Δku,superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢1𝐵Δsubscript𝐵𝑡superscriptsubscriptΓsubscript𝑘𝑢1subscriptΔsubscript𝑘𝑢\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}-\frac{1}{{B-\Delta{B_{t}}}}\Gamma_{{k_{u}}}^{-1}{\Delta_{{k_{u}}}}, (8)

where ΓksubscriptΓ𝑘\Gamma_{k} is the FIM. Then, we show that the outer product of the gradient is an asymptotically unbiased estimate of the Hessian matrix and we define the outer product matrix of the gradient at ωtkusuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢\omega_{t}^{k_{u}} as follows:

Htku≈Γtku=1B−Δ​B​∑(xi,yi)∈𝒟ku∇Fk​(xi,ωtku)​∇Fk​(xi,ωtku)⊤,superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscriptΓ𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢1𝐵Δ𝐵subscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢∇subscript𝐹𝑘subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢∇subscript𝐹𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢topH_{t}^{{k_{u}}}\approx\Gamma_{t}^{{k_{u}}}=\frac{1}{{B-\Delta B}}\sum\limits_{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\in\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}}{\nabla{F_{k}}({x_{i}},\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}})}\nabla{F_{k}}{({x_{i}},\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}})^{\top}}, (9)

where Htkusuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢H_{t}^{k_{u}} is the empirical expectation of the outer product as an approximation to the Hessian at ωtkusuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢\omega_{t}^{k_{u}}. Recall that, since the cross-entropy loss we use is negative log-likelihood, it is not difficult to obtain 𝔼xi∈𝒟ku​[∇Fku​(xi,ω∗)​∇Fku​(xi,ω∗)⊤]subscript𝔼subscript𝑥𝑖superscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢delimited-[]∇subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢subscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝜔∇subscript𝐹subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖superscript𝜔top{\mathbb{E}_{{x_{i}}\in\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}}}[\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}({x_{i}},{\omega^{*}})\nabla{F_{{k_{u}}}}{({x_{i}},{\omega^{*}})^{\top}}], where ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} is the true parameter (i.e., the Softmax distribution of the local model) obtained in the form of FIM. Additionly, to significantly reduce the computational complexity and storage while maintaining the accuracy of the approximator ΓΓ\Gamma, in DNN we leverage the diagonalization technique to approximate FIM [35, 36], i.e., d​i​a​g​(Γ)≈Γ𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔ΓΓdiag(\Gamma)\approx{\Gamma}, where d​i​a​g​(Γ)𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔Γdiag(\Gamma) is the diagonal matrix of ΓΓ\Gamma. Specifically, we only need to store the diagonal elements of ΓΓ\Gamma and make all other elements zero. Although this method can approximate the Hessian matrix efficiently, it may be affected by the variance generated by the iterative update of FL, which may lead to higher approximation errors and unstable convergence. To address this issue, this paper follows the momentum techniques used in Adam [37] and RMSProp [38] to easily apply momentum to the Hessian diagonal since it can achieve more stable and faster convergence. More specifically, let G¯tsubscript¯𝐺𝑡{{\bar{G}}_{t}} denote the Hessian diagonal with momentum, and the first and second-order moments (mtsubscript𝑚𝑡m_{t} and vtsubscript𝑣𝑡v_{t}) for Hessian momentum are computed as follows:

mt=(1−β1)​∑i=1tβ1t−i​Δi1−β1t,vt=(1−β2)​∑i=1tβ2t−i​Γi​Γi1−β2t,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑚𝑡1subscript𝛽1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑡𝑖subscriptΔ𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡1subscript𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽2𝑡𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝛽2𝑡{m_{t}}=\frac{{(1-{\beta_{1}})\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{t}{\beta_{1}^{t-i}{\Delta_{i}}}}}{{1-\beta_{1}^{t}}},{v_{t}}=\sqrt{\frac{{(1-{\beta_{2}})\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{t}{\beta_{2}^{t-i}{\Gamma_{i}}{\Gamma_{i}}}}}{{1-\beta_{2}^{t}}}}, (11)

where vt=G¯tsubscript𝑣𝑡subscript¯𝐺𝑡{v_{t}}={{\bar{G}}_{t}}, 0<β1t<β2t<10superscriptsubscript𝛽1𝑡superscriptsubscript𝛽2𝑡10<\beta_{1}^{t}<\beta_{2}^{t}<1 are the first and second moment hyperparameters that are also used in Adam. Therefore, refer to Eq. (7)–(11), Eq. (8) can be rewritten as follows: ωt+1ku=ωtku−1B−Δ​Bt​mt/vt.superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢1𝐵Δsubscript𝐵𝑡subscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}-\frac{1}{{B-\Delta{B_{t}}}}{m_{t}}/{v_{t}}. Furthermore, other normal clients perform local training, i.e., run the following update rule: ωt+1ku=ωtku−1B​mt/vt.superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1subscript𝑘𝑢superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡subscript𝑘𝑢1𝐵subscript𝑚𝑡subscript𝑣𝑡\omega_{t+1}^{{k_{u}}}=\omega_{t}^{{k_{u}}}-\frac{1}{B}{m_{t}}/{v_{t}}.

We present our federated rapid retraining algorithm, as shown in Algorithm 1. As seen in lines 1 to 3, all unlearned clients perform a mini-batch data deletion operation, i.e., split the deleted data into small batches of size B<=Rk𝐵subscript𝑅𝑘B<=R_{k} and sequentially for each of them. As a result, each unlearned client obtains a locally deleted dataset 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}. Such a method will result in multiple smaller second-order Fisher information correction steps, thereby obtaining a more effective FL model at the cost of efficiency. Then all clients start the unlearning stage and perform local training on the local dataset. In particular, the unlearned client performs local training on the locally deleted dataset 𝒟kusuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑘𝑢\mathcal{D}_{k}^{u}, while the normal clients perform local training on the original dataset 𝒟ksubscript𝒟𝑘\mathcal{D}_{k}. This is described in lines 9 to 14 and lines 18 and 25. As seen in line 16, the server uses aggregation rules such as FedAvg to iteratively aggregate the model updates uploaded by the client.

VI Theoretical Analysis

VI-A Convergence Analysis

We first introduce assumptions and then provide the convergence rate of Algorithm 1 for strongly convex objectives in Theorem 1. The norm used throughout the rest of the paper is ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} norm.

Assumption 1.

(Bounded gradients). For any model parameter ω𝜔\omega and in the sequence [ω0,ω1,…,ωt,…]subscript𝜔0subscript𝜔1…subscript𝜔𝑡…[{\omega_{0}},{\omega_{1}},\ldots,{\omega_{t}},\ldots], the norm of the gradient at every sample is bounded by a constant ε02superscriptsubscript𝜀02\varepsilon_{0}^{2}, i.e., ∀ω,i,for-all𝜔𝑖\forall\omega,i,, we have: ‖∇fi​(ω)‖⩽ε02norm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝜔superscriptsubscript𝜀02||\nabla{f_{i}}(\omega)||\leqslant{\varepsilon_{0}^{2}}.

Assumption 2.

(Lipschitz continuity). We assume that the function F:ℝd→ℝ:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\to\mathbb{R} is L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous, i.e., ∀ω1,ω2for-allsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2\forall\omega_{1},\omega_{2}, the following equation holds:

|F​(ω1)−F​(ω2)|⩽L​‖ω1−ω2‖.𝐹subscript𝜔1𝐹subscript𝜔2𝐿normsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2|F({\omega_{1}})-F({\omega_{2}})|\leqslant L||{\omega_{1}}-{\omega_{2}}||. (12)
Assumption 3.

(Strong convexity and smoothness). F​(ω)𝐹𝜔F(\omega) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex and ρ𝜌\rho-smooth with positive coefficient μ𝜇\mu if ∀ω1,ω2for-allsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2\forall{\omega_{1}},{\omega_{2}}, the following equations hold:

F​(ω1)⩾F​(ω2)+∇F​(ω2)⊤​(ω1−ω2)+μ2​‖ω1−ω2‖2.𝐹subscript𝜔1𝐹subscript𝜔2∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜔2topsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2𝜇2superscriptnormsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔22F({\omega_{1}})\geqslant F({\omega_{2}})+\nabla F{({\omega_{2}})^{\top}}({\omega_{1}}-{\omega_{2}})+\frac{\mu}{2}||{\omega_{1}}-{\omega_{2}}|{|^{2}}.\vspace{-0.5cm} (13)
F​(ω1)⩽F​(ω2)+∇F​(ω2)⊤​(ω1−ω2)+ρ2​‖ω1−ω2‖2.𝐹subscript𝜔1𝐹subscript𝜔2∇𝐹superscriptsubscript𝜔2topsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔2𝜌2superscriptnormsubscript𝜔1subscript𝜔22F({\omega_{1}})\leqslant F({\omega_{2}})+\nabla F{({\omega_{2}})^{\top}}({\omega_{1}}-{\omega_{2}})+\frac{\rho}{2}||{\omega_{1}}-{\omega_{2}}|{|^{2}}. (14)
Assumption 4.

The function F:ℝd→ℝ:𝐹→superscriptℝ𝑑ℝF:{\mathbb{R}^{d}}\to\mathbb{R} is twice continuously differentiable, ρ𝜌\rho-smooth, and μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, μ>0𝜇0\mu>0, i.e.,

μ​I⩽∇2f​(ω)⩽ρ​I,𝜇𝐼superscript∇2𝑓𝜔𝜌𝐼\mu I\leqslant{\nabla^{2}}f(\omega)\leqslant\rho I, (15)

where I∈ℝd𝐼superscriptℝ𝑑I\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and ∇2f​(ω)superscript∇2𝑓𝜔{\nabla^{2}}f(\omega) is the Hessian of gradient.

Theorem 1.

Suppose the objective function is strongly convex and smooth, and Assumption 1 holds. Thus, we have:

f​(ωt+1u)−f​(ω∗)⩽ε,𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡1𝑢𝑓superscript𝜔𝜀f(\omega_{t+1}^{u})-f({\omega^{*}})\leqslant\varepsilon, (16)

where ε=−μ2​ρ2​ε02𝜀𝜇2superscript𝜌2superscriptsubscript𝜀02\varepsilon=-\frac{\mu}{{2{\rho^{2}}}}\varepsilon_{0}^{2}.

Proof.

First, since f​(ω)𝑓𝜔f(\omega) is μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex, Eq. (16) is equivalent to the following equation:

f​(ωtu−ηt​Δ​ωt)⩽f​(ωtu)−ηt​Δt⊤​Δ​ωt+ηt2​ρ​‖Δ​ωt‖22,𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢subscript𝜂𝑡Δsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡topΔsubscript𝜔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝜌superscriptnormΔsubscript𝜔𝑡22f(\omega_{t}^{u}-{\eta_{t}}\Delta{\omega_{t}})\leqslant f(\omega_{t}^{u})-{\eta_{t}}\Delta_{t}^{\top}\Delta{\omega_{t}}+\frac{{{\eta_{t}}^{2}\rho||\Delta{\omega_{t}}|{|^{2}}}}{2},

where Δ​ωt=Ht−1​ΔtΔsubscript𝜔𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑡\Delta{\omega_{t}}=H_{t}^{-1}{\Delta_{t}} and Δt=∇f​(wtu)subscriptΔ𝑡∇𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑡𝑢\Delta_{t}=\nabla f(w_{t}^{u}). Let ϕ​(ωt)=Δt⊤​Ht−1​Δtitalic-ϕsubscript𝜔𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡topsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑡\phi({\omega_{t}})=\sqrt{\Delta_{t}^{\top}H_{t}^{-1}{\Delta_{t}}}, thus, we have: ϕ​(ωt)2=Δ​ωt⊤​(Ht)⊤​Δ​ωt⩾μ​‖Δ​ωt‖2italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡2Δsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡topsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡topΔsubscript𝜔𝑡𝜇superscriptnormΔsubscript𝜔𝑡2\phi{({\omega_{t}})^{2}}=\Delta\omega_{t}^{\top}(H_{t})^{\top}\Delta{\omega_{t}}\geqslant\mu||\Delta{\omega_{t}}|{|^{2}}. Then we can obtain:

f​(ωtu−ηt​Δ​ωt)⩽f​(ωtu)−ηt​ϕ​(ωt)2+ρ2​μ​ηt2​ϕ​(ωt)2.𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢subscript𝜂𝑡Δsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢subscript𝜂𝑡italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡2𝜌2𝜇superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡2f(\omega_{t}^{u}-{\eta_{t}}\Delta{\omega_{t}})\leqslant f(\omega_{t}^{u})-{\eta_{t}}\phi{({\omega_{t}})^{2}}+\frac{\rho}{{2\mu}}\eta_{t}^{2}\phi{({\omega_{t}})^{2}}.

We assume that the step size ηt=μρsubscript𝜂𝑡𝜇𝜌{\eta_{t}}=\frac{\mu}{\rho}, thus, f𝑓f decreases as follows:

f​(ωtu−ηt​Δ​ωt)⩽f​(ω∗)−12​ηt​ϕ​(ωt)2.𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢subscript𝜂𝑡Δsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑓superscript𝜔12subscript𝜂𝑡italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡2f(\omega_{t}^{u}-{\eta_{t}}\Delta{\omega_{t}})\leqslant f({\omega^{*}})-\frac{1}{2}{\eta_{t}}\phi{({\omega_{t}})^{2}}.

If assumption 4 holds, i.e., μ⩽Ht⩽ρ𝜇subscript𝐻𝑡𝜌\mu\leqslant{H_{t}}\leqslant\rho holds, thus, we have: ϕ​(ωt)2=ηt​Δt⊤​Ht−1​Δt⩾1ρ​‖Δt‖2italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡2subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscriptΔ𝑡topsuperscriptsubscript𝐻𝑡1subscriptΔ𝑡1𝜌superscriptnormsubscriptΔ𝑡2\phi{({\omega_{t}})^{2}}={\eta_{t}}\Delta_{t}^{\top}H_{t}^{-1}{\Delta_{t}}\geqslant\frac{1}{\rho}||{\Delta_{t}}|{|^{2}}. It can be seen from Lemma 1 that if we use FIM to approximate Hessian, the above inequality still holds. When t→∞→𝑡t\to\infty, we have ω∗←ωt←superscript𝜔subscript𝜔𝑡{\omega^{*}}\leftarrow{\omega_{t}}, thus, the following inequality holds:

f​(ωtu−ηt​Δ​ωt)−f​(ω∗)−12​ρ​ηt​‖Δt‖2=−μ2​ρ2​‖Δt‖2⩽−μ2​ρ2​ε02.𝑓superscriptsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑢subscript𝜂𝑡Δsubscript𝜔𝑡𝑓superscript𝜔12𝜌subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptnormsubscriptΔ𝑡2𝜇2superscript𝜌2superscriptnormsubscriptΔ𝑡2𝜇2superscript𝜌2superscriptsubscript𝜀02f(\omega_{t}^{u}-{\eta_{t}}\Delta{\omega_{t}})-f({\omega^{*}})-\frac{1}{{2\rho}}{\eta_{t}}||{\Delta_{t}}|{|^{2}}=-\frac{\mu}{{2{\rho^{2}}}}||{\Delta_{t}}|{|^{2}}\leqslant-\frac{\mu}{{2{\rho^{2}}}}\varepsilon_{0}^{2}.

Furthermore, as long as Lemma 1 is true, the above inequality can be established regardless of whether the diagonal FIM or FIM is used to approximate the Hessian. ∎

VI-B Complexity Analysis

Here we give a formal analysis of the time and space complexity of the proposed algorithm. We define the number of parameters of the model as p𝑝p, the number of samples is n𝑛n, and the dimension of the feature is d𝑑d.

Time Complexity: Let f​(p)𝑓𝑝f(p) be the time complexity of forward propagation, then the time complexity of one step backpropagation is at most 5​f​(p)5𝑓𝑝5f(p) [39], so the total complexity of computing the derivative of each training sample is 6​f​(p)6𝑓𝑝6f(p). Thus, the total time complexity of the baseline at the step is 6​f​(p)​[ku​(B−Δ​B)+kc​B]6𝑓𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑢𝐵Δ𝐵subscript𝑘𝑐𝐵6f(p)[{k_{u}}(B-\Delta B)+{k_{c}}B]. If we use a block diagonal structure with a block size of b𝑏b and iterate over (B−Δ​B)𝐵Δ𝐵(B-\Delta B) samples in the diagonal estimation, the total computational complexity of the proposed algorithm at the step is 6​f​(p)​[ku​(B−Δ​B)+kc​B]+k​𝒪​(b​(B−Δ​B)​d)6𝑓𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑢𝐵Δ𝐵subscript𝑘𝑐𝐵𝑘𝒪𝑏𝐵Δ𝐵𝑑6f(p)[{k_{u}}(B-\Delta B)+{k_{c}}B]+k\mathcal{O}(b(B-\Delta B)d). Suppose there are Tbsubscript𝑇𝑏T_{b} (Tusubscript𝑇𝑢T_{u}) iterations in the retraining process. Then the running time TbsubscriptT𝑏{\rm T}_{b} of baseline method will be 6​f​(p)​[ku​(B−Δ​B)+kc​B]​Tb∗tb6𝑓𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑢𝐵Δ𝐵subscript𝑘𝑐𝐵subscript𝑇𝑏subscript𝑡𝑏6f(p)[{k_{u}}(B-\Delta B)+{k_{c}}B]{T_{b}}*{t_{b}}. The proposed algorithm’s total running time TusubscriptT𝑢{\rm T}_{u} is [6​f​(p)​[ku​(B−Δ​B)+kc​B]+k​𝒪​(b​(B−Δ​B)​d)]​Tu∗tudelimited-[]6𝑓𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑢𝐵Δ𝐵subscript𝑘𝑐𝐵𝑘𝒪𝑏𝐵Δ𝐵𝑑subscript𝑇𝑢subscript𝑡𝑢\big{[}6f(p)[{k_{u}}(B-\Delta B)+{k_{c}}B]+k\mathcal{O}(b(B-\Delta B)d)\big{]}{T_{u}}*{t_{u}}. Accordingly, let v𝑣v denote the speed-up factor which is defined as follows:

v=(TuTb)−1=[Tu∗tuTb∗tb​(1+k​𝒪​(b​(B−Δ​B)​d)6​f​(p)​[ku​(B−Δ​B)+kc​B])]−1,𝑣superscriptsubscriptT𝑢subscriptT𝑏1superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑢subscript𝑡𝑢subscript𝑇𝑏subscript𝑡𝑏1𝑘𝒪𝑏𝐵Δ𝐵𝑑6𝑓𝑝delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑢𝐵Δ𝐵subscript𝑘𝑐𝐵1v={(\frac{{{{\rm T}_{u}}}}{{{{\rm T}_{b}}}})^{-1}}={[\frac{{{T_{u}}*{t_{u}}}}{{{T_{b}}*{t_{b}}}}(1+\frac{{k\mathcal{O}(b(B-\Delta B)d)}}{{6f(p)[{k_{u}}(B-\Delta B)+{k_{c}}B]}})]^{-1}}, (17)

where tusubscript𝑡𝑢t_{u} and tbsubscript𝑡𝑏t_{b} are the running time of one round of training of Algorithm 1 and the baseline, respectively. The cost of this estimation is one diagonal FIM (to compute d​i​a​g​(ω)𝑑𝑖𝑎𝑔𝜔diag(\omega)), which is equivalent to one gradient backpropagation [40, 41], i.e., k​𝒪​(b​(B−Δ​B)​d)≈5​k​f​(p)𝑘𝒪𝑏𝐵Δ𝐵𝑑5𝑘𝑓𝑝k\mathcal{O}(b(B-\Delta B)d)\approx 5kf(p), thus, we have:

v≈[Tu∗tuTb∗tb​(1+5​k6​[ku​(B−Δ​B)+kc​B])]−1.𝑣superscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝑇𝑢subscript𝑡𝑢subscript𝑇𝑏subscript𝑡𝑏15𝑘6delimited-[]subscript𝑘𝑢𝐵Δ𝐵subscript𝑘𝑐𝐵1v\approx{[\frac{{{T_{u}}*{t_{u}}}}{{{T_{b}}*{t_{b}}}}(1+\frac{{5k}}{{6[{k_{u}}(B-\Delta B)+{k_{c}}B]}})]^{-1}}. (18)

Space Complexity: In the proposed algorithm, we use the diagonal technique to approximate the Fisher information matrix and update it with the mini-batch gradients. Specifically, as we employ a block-diagonal structure with blocks of size b𝑏b, it needs a memory of size 𝒪​(d​b)𝒪𝑑𝑏\mathcal{O}(db) to compute the estimated diagonal Fisher information [21]. As shown in our experiments, this allows us to support fairly large models and sample sets.

VII Experiments

VII-A Experiment Setup

To evaluate the performance of our proposed design, we conduct extensive experiments on four representative public datasets. All experiments were developed using Python 3.7 and PyTorch 1.7, and executed on a server with an NVIDIA GeForce RTX2080 Ti GPU and an Intel Xeon Silver 4210 CPU.

Datasets: In this paper, we adopt four real-world image datasets for evaluations, i.e., MNIST111http://yann.lecun.com/exdb/mnist/, Fashion-MNIST222https://github.com/zalandoresearch/fashion-mnist, CIFAR-10333https://www.cs.toronto.edu/ kriz/cifar.html, and CelebA444https://mmlab.ie.cuhk.edu.hk/projects/CelebA.html (a.k.a. Federated LEAF [42] dataset). The datasets cover different attributes, dimensions, and number of categories, as shown in Table I, allowing us to effectively explore the unlearning utility of the proposed algorithm. To simulate the real environment settings of FL, we evenly distribute the four training datasets to all clients.

Models: In this experiment, we use a simple CNN model, i.e., CNN with 2 convolutional layers followed by 1 fully connected layer for classification tasks on the MNIST dataset and Fashion-MNIST dataset, the AlexNet model for classification tasks on the CIFAR-10 dataset, and the ResNet-18 model for classification tasks on the CelebA dataset. In particular, we performed a gender classification task on the CelebA dataset.

Hyperparameters: In our design, we consider the cross-silo FL scenario. We set the number of clients K=10𝐾10K=10, proportion of client participation q=1𝑞1q=1, local epoch El​o​c​a​l=1subscript𝐸𝑙𝑜𝑐𝑎𝑙1{E_{local}}=1, mini-batch size B∈{128,256,512,1024,2048}𝐵12825651210242048B\in\{128,256,512,1024,2048\}, learning rate η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001, delete rate r={2%,1.5%,1%,0.5%}𝑟percent2percent1.5percent1percent0.5r=\{2\%,1.5\%,1\%,0.5\%\}, training round T=200𝑇200T=200, the block size b=3𝑏3b=3, and the momentum parameter β1=0.9subscript𝛽10.9\beta_{1}=0.9, β2=0.999subscript𝛽20.999\beta_{2}=0.999.

Federated Unlearning Pipeline: First, we follow the above hyperparameters setting to start the training stage in the FL pipeline. Then, we use the obtained model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} for inference or unlearning. Second, if the clients initiate several data erasure requests, the server will start the unlearning stage after receiving all the requests to forget the contribution of the erased data. Notably, we define the percentage of client-side deleted data to all training data as the deletion rate r𝑟r. Finally, the server reinitializes the global model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} and uses Algorithm 1 or the baseline algorithm (see below) to perform rapid retraining to obtain the new model ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u}.

Baseline: Retraining from Scratch. This method is to delete the erased training samples and to retrain the FL model from scratch by using the remaining dataset as the training dataset.

Evaluation Metrics: First, we will evaluate the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, and the speed-up of our retraining algorithm running time is defined: v=TbTu​x𝑣subscriptT𝑏subscriptT𝑢xv=\frac{{{\mathrm{T}_{b}}}}{{{\mathrm{T}_{u}}}}\mathrm{x}. Second, to fairly compare model utility, we report the performance achieved by a given model relative to the performance of the baseline model. To this end, we use the Symmetric Absolute Percentage Error (SAPE) defined as: εs=SAPE​(A​c​ct​e​s​t∗,A​c​ct​e​s​tu)=|A​c​ct​e​s​tu−A​c​ct​e​s​t∗||A​c​ct​e​s​t∗|+|A​c​ct​e​s​tu|subscript𝜀𝑠SAPE𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑢𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑢𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑢\varepsilon_{s}=\mathrm{SAPE}(Acc_{test}^{*},Acc_{test}^{u})=\frac{{|Acc_{test}^{u}-Acc_{test}^{*}|}}{{|Acc_{test}^{*}|+|Acc_{test}^{u}|}}, where A​c​ct​e​s​t∗𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡Acc_{test}^{*} denotes the accuracy of the model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} obtained by the baseline algorithm on the test dataset 𝒟t​e​s​tsubscript𝒟𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡\mathcal{D}_{test}, and A​c​ct​e​s​tu𝐴𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑡𝑒𝑠𝑡𝑢Acc_{test}^{u} denotes the accuracy of the model ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} obtained by the proposed algorithm on the same dataset.

VII-B Evaluation

Our evaluation is four-fold: (i) To show the data erasure efficiency of Algorithm 1, we report the speed-up of the proposed algorithm; (ii) To prove the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm, we compare it with the baseline in terms of accuracy and SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} under different delete rates; (iii) To explore the parameter sensitivity of the proposed algorithm, we conduct extensive case studies around the parameters kusubscript𝑘𝑢k_{u} and B𝐵B. (iv) To answer whether our algorithm can effectively realize unlearning, we conduct an analysis with experimental results.

First, we evaluate the data erasure efficiency of the proposed algorithm under different deletion rates r𝑟r settings. Specifically, we fixed the number of unlearned clients ku=1subscript𝑘𝑢1k_{u}=1, the learning rate η=0.001𝜂0.001\eta=0.001, and batch size B=2048𝐵2048B=2048. Then, we choose the deletion rate r={2%,1.5%,1%,0.5%}𝑟percent2percent1.5percent1percent0.5r=\{2\%,1.5\%,1\%,0.5\%\} to explore the data erasure efficiency of Algorithm 1. As shown in Fig. 2 and Fig. 3, we highlight the superiority of the proposed algorithm by computing the speed-up factor v𝑣v and the running time of each round. For each dataset, it can be clearly seen that the data erasure of the proposed algorithm is always higher than that of the baseline method, which is because that our algorithm utilizes gradient information and curvature information to find a “better” descent direction, thereby reducing the time for retraining. We can also see that the data erasure ability of our algorithm is more efficient on large datasets (i.e., CIFAR-10 (v=7.1​x𝑣7.1xv=7.1\mathrm{x}) and CelebA (v=9.6​x𝑣9.6xv=9.6\mathrm{x}). The reason is that if the baseline method uses mini-batch SGD to retrain on a large dataset, this requires multiple recalculations of gradient information for the same sample, which greatly increases the cost of retraining. In Fig. 3, the running time of each round of the proposed algorithm is very close to that of the baseline, which is in line with the results of the time and space complexity analysis in Section VI-B. This experiment also shows that Algorithm 1 meets the goal G4 and G5.

Second, Table II shows the model utility of Algorithm 1 and the baseline algorithm. In addition, we also report the SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} between the accuracy of the unlearned models produced by the two algorithms. Experimental results show that the performance of the proposed algorithm is comparable to that of the baseline, i.e., meet the goal G3. For example, when r=0.5%𝑟percent0.5r=0.5\%, the performance of Algorithm 1 on the MNIST dataset is slightly higher than the baseline. Furthermore, when we increase r𝑟r, the performance of the proposed algorithm can still be comparable to the baseline. Obviously, the baseline method achieves stable high performance at the expense of retraining costs. Although our algorithm uses diagonal empirical FIM to approximate the Hessian matrix and damages the model utility, the use of the momentum technique makes up for this shortcoming. Similarly, this shows that our method satisfies the goal G3.

Third, we report the sensitivity of Algorithm 1 to the parameters kusubscript𝑘𝑢k_{u} and B𝐵B. We use the controlled variable method to analyze the influence of the parameters kusubscript𝑘𝑢k_{u} and B𝐵B on the data erasure efficiency of the algorithm. Specifically, when we explore the influence of parameter kusubscript𝑘𝑢k_{u}, we fix the deletion rate r=1%𝑟percent1r=1\% and B=2048𝐵2048B=2048; on the contrary, when exploring the parameter B𝐵B, we fix the deletion rate r=1%𝑟percent1r=1\% and ku=1subscript𝑘𝑢1k_{u}=1. Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 present the total running time of the two algorithms, where Fig. 3 shows that kusubscript𝑘𝑢k_{u} has no obvious effect on speed-up; Fig. 4 shows that B𝐵B has a significant impact on speed-up. Recall that these experimental results are consistent with the results of the analysis of time and space complexity in Section VI-B. Notably, the unlearning efficiency of Algorithm 1 is significantly higher than the baseline method in the case of large batch size. The reason is that in this case, this algorithm can utilize more samples to compute a more accurate diagonal empirical FIM, thereby quickly realizing unlearning.

Last, we conduct an analysis with experimental results to show the data erasure effectiveness of the proposed algorithm. Concretely, we assume that {(xi,yi)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑖1𝑛\{({x_{i}},{y_{i}})\}_{i=1}^{n} is the input sample randomly sampled from the original dataset, where xi∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-tosubscript𝑥𝑖𝒩0superscript𝜎2{x_{i}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,{\sigma^{2}}), and {(xiu,yiu)}i=1nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑢𝑖1𝑛\{(x_{i}^{u},y_{i}^{u})\}_{i=1}^{n} is the input sample randomly sampled from the deleted dataset, where xiu∼𝒩​(0,σ2)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑢𝒩0superscript𝜎2{x_{i}^{u}}\sim\mathcal{N}(0,{\sigma^{2}}). Suppose f​(xi)𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖f(x_{i}) is the output of the global model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} on the original dataset, and fu​(xiu)subscript𝑓𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑢f_{u}(x_{i}^{u}) is the output of the global model ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} after unlearning on the deleted dataset. If the distribution of model ωusuperscript𝜔𝑢\omega^{u} and the distribution of model ω∗superscript𝜔\omega^{*} are identical, then the following Equation holds: du=∑i=1n‖f​(xi)−fu​(xiu)‖≈0,n→∞.formulae-sequencesubscript𝑑𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛norm𝑓subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑓𝑢superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖𝑢0→𝑛{d_{u}}=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{n}{||f({x_{i}})-{f_{u}}(x_{i}^{u})||}\approx 0,n\to\infty. In fact, the distance dusubscript𝑑𝑢d_{u} in the above equation is equivalent to the evaluation index SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} designed by us. For example, for the CelebA dataset, the SAPESAPE\mathrm{SAPE} value of our Algorithm 1 is 9.772 ×10−4absentsuperscript104\times 10^{-4}, which shows that the model generated by this algorithm and the model generated by the baseline are approximately identical. Therefore, these results have shown that the proposed algorithm meets the requirements of Definition 2 and goals G1, and G2.

VIII Conclusion

In this paper, we present a federated unlearning algorithm, providing efficient and effective unlearning services for data holders in FL. Specifically, we leverage the first-order Taylor expansion approximation technique to customize a rapid retraining algorithm based on diagonal experience FIM. For boosting model utility, we introduce the momentum technique into the unlearning update strategy to further alleviate the negative impact caused by approximation errors. Furthermore, we provide a comprehensive theoretical analysis and experimental support for the proposed algorithm. The performance advantage of our design has been empirically proven on some medium-scale public datasets, revealing its great potential in building data deletion FL services for various applications.
